qas.question: What year the "second generation" of tram system began to operate in France?
When was the original system discontinued?
How is the circuit of the third rail divided?
Does energized segment of third rail pose the threat to pedestrians if uncovered?

plausible_answers.text: the "second generation" tram/streetcar system in Bordeaux, France

qas.question: An old approach to avoiding overhead wires is taken by what system?
What system has been adopted in all sections of the new tram systems in Reims, France?
When did the new tram system in Paris, France open?
When did the new trans system in Achnor, France open?

plausible_answers.text: the "second generation" tram/streetcar system in Bordeaux, France

qas.question: The circuit is left undivided in what system?

context: A new approach to avoiding overhead wires is taken by <b4_0><b5_0><b8_0>the "second generation" tram/streetcar system<b5_0/> in Bordeaux, France<b8_0/><b4_0/> (entry into service of the first line in December <a0_0>2003<a0_0/>; original system discontinued in <a1_0>1958<a1_0/>) with its APS (alimentation par sol – ground current feed). This involves a third rail which is flush with the surface like the tops of the running rails. The circuit is divided into segments with each segment energized in turn by sensors from the car as it passes over it, the remainder of the third rail remaining "dead". Since each <a2_0>energized segment<a2_0/> is completely covered by the lengthy articulated cars, and goes dead before being "uncovered" by the passage of the vehicle, there is <a3_0>no danger<a3_0/> to pedestrians. This system has also been adopted in some sections of the new tram systems in Reims, France (opened <b6_0>2011<b6_0/>) and Angers, France (also opened <b7_0>2011<b7_0/>). Proposals are in place for a number of other new services including Dubai, UAE; Barcelona, Spain; Florence, Italy; Marseille, France; Gold Coast, Australia; Washington, D.C., U.S.A.; Brasília, Brazil and Tours, France.
